node.text: We need to call a time-out on "win-at-all-costs" culture and define what success really means, says Valorie Kondos Field, the former UCLA women's gymnastics coach. "As parents, as coaches, as leaders, we can no longer lead from a place where winning is our only metric of success, where our ego sits center stage," she explains in her TED Talk. "Real success is developing champions in life for our world — win or lose." Watch her brutally honest talk on the human consequences of our culture of winning here: http://t.ted.com/QCpwy7i

node.title: Why We Need to Redefine Success

node.text: Deep beneath the ocean's surface — 650 to 3,000 feet below! — lies a dark, frigid and rarely explored area called the “twilight zone”. It gets almost no sunlight and hovers around 40°F. 🥶 And the bottom dwellers that reside there? Just as otherworldly as the name of their home implies — they have bioluminescent bodies, tentacles galore, singular ways of moving and mating, and all kinds of other unique characteristics! But these critters are not just cool looking, they also play an important role in keeping CO2 out of our atmosphere. “The animals feed near the surface," says ocean scientist Heidi Sosik of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (@whoi.ocean). "They bring carbon in their food into the deep waters, where some of that carbon can stay behind and remain isolated from the atmosphere for hundreds or even thousands of years.” Watch her full talk on how she's leading the effort to protect and explore these uncharted waters and their inhabitants — and preserve their ability to protect the Earth’s climate: http://t.ted.com/rVrptCo

node.title: The Incredible Sea Creatures of the Twilight Zone

node.text: Do you struggle with feelings of shame? You’re not alone! So many of us experience shame in our everyday lives, according to vulnerability researcher and author @BreneBrown. "If you put shame in a petri dish, it needs three things to grow exponentially —secrecy, silence and judgment,” she explains. So how can you overcome these feelings? The key is empathy, says Brown. "If you put the same amount [of shame] in a petri dish and douse it with empathy, it can't survive." To learn about the amazing things that can happen when you confront your shame head on, watch Brené Brown’s full TED Talk here: http://t.ted.com/TSln3xB

node.title: We Need to Talk About Shame

node.text: Feeling stressed? In her TED Talk, Darria Long MD (@drdarria) shows how you can take back control even when your life starts to get "crazy busy". And she knows all about stress — she's an ER doctor! Her secret: Just like with patients in the hospital, you have to triage — or prioritize — the responsibilities that must be tackled first *and* then plan for the ones you know are coming. "Our brains all process stress in similar fundamental ways," she says. "But how we react to it has been shown by research to be modifiable, whether it's emergencies or just daily, day-in, day-out stress." To get more advice to help you juggle packed schedules and daily demands, watch her full talk here: http://t.ted.com/BBbZqZ7

node.title: Simple Ways to Reduce Stress Right Now

node.text: You may be hearing more about trans people these days — but contrary to what some may think, they've been around for a *long* time. Gender variance in humans is quite old, says actor and activist Samy Nour Younes. And knowing this history could make a big difference in public understanding and acceptance. He says, "Imagine how the conversation would shift if we acknowledge just how long trans people have been demanding equality." In his TED Talk, he shares the long and vibrant history of the #trans community — that we don't usually hear about. Watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/KTQ2mnA #Pride

node.title: The Long and Vibrant History of the Trans Community

node.text: Here are 2 pieces of life advice from actor @EthanHawke: 1) Find a way to express yourself; and 2) Don't worry if you're any good at it. In his TED Talk, he shares how he found an outlet for his creativity in acting and why creativity is for everyone. "Art's not a luxury; it's actually sustenance. We need it," he says. Watch his full talk on finding what you love and getting in touch with creativity: http://t.ted.com/i9IM0ay

node.title: The Secret to Discovering Your Creativity

node.text: Lawyer Bryan Stevenson (@itsbryan_stevenson) has dedicated his life to representing the marginalized and wrongly accused and fighting racial discrimination in the US justice system. As human beings, each person's survival is tied to everyone else's, he explains in his TED Talk. And we cannot evolve as a society until we deal with inequality. "Ultimately, you judge the character of a society, not by how they treat their rich and the powerful and the privileged," Stevenson explains, "but by how they treat the poor, the condemned, the incarcerated." Watch his full talk and see why he got the longest standing ovation in TED's history: http://t.ted.com/wwuN4Bw

node.title: We Need to Talk About an Injustice

node.text: Are double standards setting up girls to fail? Yes, says education activist and founder of Girls Who Code @ReshmaSaujani. In her TED Talk, she explains that while young boys are taught to be brave risk-takers, young girls are taught to be cautious perfectionists. These stereotypes stick with them even as they grow up and shape the lives they build for themselves. "I need each of you to tell every young woman you know to be comfortable with imperfection," declares Saujani. “We have to show them that they will be loved and accepted not for being perfect but for being courageous.“ For more on what it really takes to raise young women who will be confident *and* courageous, watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/HnFGaSu

node.title: We Must Raise Girls to Be Brave, Not Perfect

node.text: What's the biggest public health threat we're *not* talking about? Childhood trauma. It's not just something you “get over” when you grow up — and it doesn't just affect your mental health, according to Nadine Burke Harris MD (@nadineburkeharris), pediatrician and the Surgeon General of California. In fact, people who experience neglect and abuse as a child often show inhibited brain development; it's also been linked to heart disease, lung cancer and lower life expectancy. "The single most important thing that we need today is the courage to look this problem in the face and say, 'This is real and this is all of us,'" says Dr. Burke Harris. To learn more about why and how childhood trauma impacts our health in the long run, watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/XPZ14Mi

node.title: How Childhood Trauma Affects Health Across a Lifetime

node.text: In honor of #TeacherAppreciationWeek, this one goes out to all of the teachers who are making a difference each and every day. In this classic talk from 2013, the late Rita Pierson — who was a teacher for 40 years — calls on educators to connect with their students on a personal level and marvel at the amazing things that can come out of this relationship. "Every child deserves a champion, an adult who will never give up on them," she says. "Is this job tough? You betcha. But it is not impossible. We're educators. We're born to make a difference." Know a teacher like this? Tag them in the comments below and let them know how much you care! Watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/3pfti8C

node.title: Why Every Kid Needs a Champion

node.text: It’s #ArborDay! 🌳 Join us as we reflect on this question: "If trees could speak, what would they say to us humans?" Quite a lot, says novelist Elif Shafak (@shafakelif) — and we should be listening to them. In a talk for @TEDCountdown, here's what she imagines some of these majestic figures might express: "We're older than you and your kind. Listen to what we have to tell, because hidden inside our story is the past and the future of humanity." Watch the rest of her beautifully poetic and sometimes heartbreaking reflection here: http://t.ted.com/xLnozL1

node.text: It’s #EarthDay — and we need to talk about climate change. Yes, all of us. Even with the people in our lives who don't believe it’s a serious issue … or real. And the best way to do that is to speak from your heart, according to climate scientist @KatharineHayhoe. "Start by sharing why it matters to [you]. Begin with genuinely shared values," she says in her TED Talk. “We don't have to be a liberal tree hugger to care about a changing climate. All we have to be is a human living on this planet." To learn more about what really motivates people to take action on climate change, watch her full talk: http://t.ted.com/5BADi4c

node.title: What You Can Do Right Now to Fight Climate Change

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 21, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
We bet you've never seen an apartment quite like this before! It's full of rounded shapes, bright and bold colors, and the floors are a bit bouncy. This wacky Tokyo building — created by artist Arakawa and poet Madeline Gins — shows us how our environments can keep us feeling happy, alive and engaged. And it's just one of the examples that designer Ingrid Fetell Lee shares in her TED Talk about  finding *and* creating joy in our everyday lives. What other things can inspire smiles and delight? "Round things, pops of bright color, symmetrical shapes, a sense of abundance and multiplicity, a feeling of lightness or elevation," says Lee. Or, if you want to translate those into objects, think: Cherry blossoms, bubbles, hot air balloons, googly eyes, rainbows and ice creams cones with sprinkles. Watch her talk at the link in our bio to learn more about how you can bring joy into your world.

[Photo Credit: @ingridfetell // @aestheticsofjoy ]

node.text: It's easy to let social media, email, TV and work and life demands distract us from what's going on in our heads and hearts — but this is not helping us in the long run. To find fulfillment and contentment, we need to slow down and just be with whatever's coming up for us, says author Pico Iyer. In an interview with podcast host Guy Raz and Buddhist monk Matthieu Ricard, he shares how taking time to be still — physically and mentally — can help you find clarity and peace. "Every day there are small moments when we have a choice," he says. "Will we take in more stuff, or just clear our minds out for a bit?" To read their full conversation, click the link in our bio. #MondayMotivation

node.text:
Did you know: Some researchers believe that sharks' up close encounters with humans may possibly have more to do with these creatures' curiosity and confusion than their appetite. That's why knowing *why* sharks act the way they do could make them a whole lot less scary. (Okay, maybe just a little less scary ...) Underwater cinematographer Dan Abbott (@sharkman_dan), who specializes in documenting and speaking up for sharks, says understanding these vilified animals can help us live alongside them in peace — and protect them. "When we stop dumbing these animals down to the mindless eating machines that they’ve been made out to be and allow ourselves to understand them," he says, "that’s when it leads to co-existence." Click the link in our bio to learn about 4 fascinating behaviors of great white shark (like mouthing, bumping and breaching), the only thing that really terrifies them (climate change!) and the critical role they play in maintaining a healthy ocean.⁠
⁠
Photo: Dan Abbott (@sharkman_dan)

node.text: We need to call a time-out on "win-at-all-costs" culture and define what success really means, says Valorie Kondos Field, the former UCLA women's gymnastics coach. "As parents, as coaches, as leaders, we can no longer lead from a place where winning is our only metric of success, where our ego sits center stage," she explains in her TED Talk. "Real success is developing champions in life for our world — win or lose." Watch her brutally honest talk on the human consequences of our culture of winning here: http://t.ted.com/QCpwy7i

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "A hallmark of wisdom is knowing when to grit and when to quit." ADAM GRANT ORGANIZATIONAL PSYCHOLOGIST TED'.

node.text: Are the goals you've been pursuing still the ones you really want? Is it time to reevaluate what's most important to you? In his TED Talk, organizational psychologist (and TED Audio Collective podcast host!) @AdamGrant shares the secret to continued growth, success and happiness in our lives: Every once in a while, we need to rethink what we're doing *and* how we're doing it. "We live in a culture that worships at the altar of hustle and prays to the high priest of grit, but sometimes, that leads us to keep going when we should stop to think again," he says. "The routines that help us today can become the ruts we get trapped in tomorrow." Watch his full talk on the power of rethinking at the link in our bio. #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 11, 2021.

node.text:
Is it a drone? A robot? What is this thing??? Well, it’s a whole lot of things! "Sculpture T-24-L" — an installation by artist and @TEDFellow Shih Chieh Huang (@shihchiehhuang1234) — was made from trash bags, LED lights, plastic sheets, a Tupperware container and a highlighter pen — and comes to life when inflated by computer cooling fans! Huang is known for using everyday items like discarded toys, circuit boards and more to make his kinetic structures — just one of the many ways that he breathes new life into found objects (and even trash) and turn them into art. “Don’t forget the humanity behind all the stuff around us,” he says. See more of Huang's playful, dynamic art at the link in out bio.⁠
⁠
[Photo: Megan Paetzhold; Courtesy of the artist and Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, New York]

node.text: Deep beneath the ocean's surface — 650 to 3,000 feet below! — lies a dark, frigid and rarely explored area called the “twilight zone”. It gets almost no sunlight and hovers around 40°F. 🥶 And the bottom dwellers that reside there? Just as otherworldly as the name of their home implies — they have bioluminescent bodies, tentacles galore, singular ways of moving and mating, and all kinds of other unique characteristics! But these critters are not just cool looking, they also play an important role in keeping CO2 out of our atmosphere. “The animals feed near the surface," says ocean scientist Heidi Sosik of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (@whoi.ocean). "They bring carbon in their food into the deep waters, where some of that carbon can stay behind and remain isolated from the atmosphere for hundreds or even thousands of years.” Watch her full talk on how she's leading the effort to protect and explore these uncharted waters and their inhabitants — and preserve their ability to protect the Earth’s climate: http://t.ted.com/rVrptCo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 07, 2021. May be an image of 4 people and text that says 'TED If you're depressed, if you're anxious, you're not weak, you're not craży. You're a human being with unmet needs.'.

node.text: Do we need to change the way that we approach treating depression and anxiety? Yes, says journalist @Johann.Hari — drugs should not be our only solution. "I was only able to start changing my life when I realized depression is not a malfunction; it's a signal," he explains in his TED Talk. "We need to talk less about chemical imbalances and more about the imbalances in the way we live." Visit the link in our bio to learn more about the 2 causes of depression and anxiety that Hari says no one is talking about — along with 2 promising solutions.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 05, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "There's something inside you that made you keep trying despite everyone who told you to quit." SHANE KOYCZAN POET TED'.

node.text: How will *you* keep trying today? Poet @Shane_Koyczan's spoken word poem “To This Day" poignantly details what it's like to be different, outcast and bullied. In his talk, he shares how he learned to love himself even when he thought he couldn't. "If you can't see anything beautiful about yourself," he says, "get a better mirror, look a little closer." Visit the link in our bio to see Koyczan’s passionate performance on the TED stage. #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 03, 2021. May be an image of sky.

node.text: You are made of star bursts! 💥 Seriously. All matter on Earth is composed of atoms, and that matter includes our bodies. And the heavier atoms — basically everything besides hydrogen and helium — are only created when stars explode. So every time you breathe in oxygen, you’re actually taking in atoms born from a supernova explosion that occurred somewhere in our galaxy. The iron in our blood? The calcium in our bones? Also came from stars going boom. Visit the link in our bio to learn more about the mind-blowing history of the atoms in our bodies — and in the universe.

Want to try therapy but not sure how to choose a therapist? We’ve teamed up with our friends @SadGirlsClub to put together this helpful guide featuring advice from clinical mental health therapist @taylorblosssom of Well Wildflower. At the end of the day, therapy is all about *you* — it's your time and your space to learn about yourself and work through your issues. That’s why it’s helpful to treat the first few sessions more like a date than a job interview — you and your therapist are equals in the getting-to-know-you process. Similar to dating, it usually takes several meetings with a therapist before you know if they're a good fit for you. To learn more about what to ask, expect and look for when seeing a new therapist, visit the link in our bio to read Taylor's interview with Sad Girls Club's @BriannePatrice.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1 Find out what your therapist's style is Ask them: "How do you do therapy?" Listen for: How they like to work with their clients and what aspects of their clients' lives, thoughts and behaviors they're most interested in exploring with them.'.

Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Unsure if they're a good fit? Think about the people in your life you usually turn to for support. What type of communication -venting, feedback, advice, something else- makes you feel like you've worked through stuff? Knowing this can help you identify the kind of therapist you want.'.

Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says '2 Give it time like 6 sessions It will take a while for the two of you to get to know each other, so stay open and resist the urge to call it quits after just one or two sessions.'.

Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'These initial sessions will allow the therapist to learn how you handle the problems in your life and come up with an approach to help you address the issues you' been talking about. But if you think a therapist is absolutely wrong for you, there's no need for you to stick it out for 6 sessions.'.

Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says '3 Don't ghost your therapist If you decide they aren't right for you, have an open conversation conversatior with them. Don't do this over email or text. We know this sounds *super* uncomfortable, so try this: Be direct. Just tell them what didn' 't work for you, why you feel it's time to move on and what they can improve on.'.

Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'At the end of the day, therapy is all about *you* it should be a safe space where you can be as vulnerable and as open as you want, without any consequences. And all of that starts with finding the right therapist.'.
Photo by TED Talks on July 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'For more tips on how to find a mental health health professional that best meets your needs, visit the link in in our bio.'.

Photo by TED Talks on June 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '3 Tips for Being a Trans Ally FROM TRANS ADVOCATE MICAH EAMES TED 1 Share your pronouns Add them to your social bios and email signatures to show allyship and keep trans people from standing out for sharing theirs. 2 Listen to trans people Trans folks are often left out of telling their own stories. Learn directly from them by seeking out their books, films and podcasts. 3 Take action Use your voice to support trans rights. Making meaningful change requires many voices not just theirs to call for it.'.

node.text: Yes, #Pride month is officially ending, but it’s important to show up for trans people year-round! 🏳️‍⚧️ Not sure how you can support transgender, non-binary, genderqueer and other folks who make up this community? Here are 3 helpful tips from trans advocate (and TED employee) @MicahEames about how those who are cisgender — individuals that identify with the gender they were assigned at birth — can be allies to trans people. Want to hear more from Micah? Visit the link in our bio to watch his TED original video on how you can have tricky conversations at work about anything!
